title: 109_s1291
content: The "Pascua Yaqui Mineral Rights Act of 2005" defines key terms such as Secretary, State, and Tribe. It also addresses the acquisition of subsurface mineral interests. The Secretary, in coordination with the Attorney General and with State consent, must acquire subsurface rights, title, and interests in specific tribally-owned parcels through eminent domain within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must acquire subsurface rights in specific tribally-owned parcels through eminent domain within 180 days of the Act's enactment in Pima County, Arizona. The Secretary must pay the State for acquiring subsurface mineral interests through a mineral assessment, negotiation, or appraisal report if agreement cannot be reached. The Secretary must acquire subsurface mineral interests only after the State accepts payment in full consideration, and the acquisition extinguishes all other parties' rights to the acquired interests. The Tribe agrees to reimburse the Secretary for costs related to acquiring subsurface mineral interests, with market value determined according to specific standards. Additional terms and conditions may be required by the Secretary for the acquisition. The Secretary may impose additional terms and conditions to protect the interests of the United States and any valid existing right in acquiring subsurface mineral interests. SEC. 4. INTERESTS TAKEN INTO TRUST. The Secretary shall take into trust for the Tribe the subsurface rights to specified parcels in Pima County, Arizona, excluding certain sections. The Secretary will take into trust for the Tribe the subsurface rights to specified parcels in Pima County, Arizona, with the Tribe only responsible for transaction costs related to the assessment, review, and transfer of the rights.
